thread.title: Corruption Currents: Trump Asserts ‘Absolute Immunity’ in Emoluments Lawsuit

author: Ben DiPietro
title: Corruption Currents: Trump Asserts ‘Absolute Immunity’ in Emoluments Lawsuit
text:
0 COMMENTS Photo: MIKE THEILER/BLOOMBERG NEWS
A daily roundup of corruption news from across the Web. We also provide a daily roundup of important risk & compliance stories vi a our daily newsletter, The Morning Risk Report, which readers can sign up for here . Follow us on Twitter at @WSJRisk.
Bribery:
The head of mining company Rio Tinto Ltd . pledged the company would defend itself against bribery and fraud accusations. (News.com.au)
Soccer governing body FIFA banned a former El Salvador coach for two years for his role in an attempt to pay players in a World Cup qualifying match. (AP, Reuters)
A former Netflix Inc. executive is facing accusations of taking kickbacks; his attorney said he denies the allegations. (SJMN)
A co-defendant in a bribery case involving a former aide to New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo is expected to enter an agreement with prosecutors on Friday. (Syracuse.com)
A drug company paid doctors as part of a speaker program. Prosecutors had a different word for what the company was doing: kickbacks. (NYT)
Northern Ireland’s police commissioner says an investigation has cleared him of wrongdoing related to how the police department handled a bribery inquiry. (IT, BT)
Money Laundering:
Criminals are using falsified trade invoices to launder money in Pakistan. (DT)
Taiwan issued its first report on money laundering. (TN, TT)
Cybercrime/Privacy:
Palestinian lawmakers are moving ahead with plans to pass a controversial cybercrime measure. (AM)
Sentencing is set for May 25 in the U.K. for a cybercriminal who pleaded guilty last year to hacking a fast-food chain. (USAT)
Sanctions:
Ukraine said it would replicate U.S. sanctions against Russian oligarchs and companies. (Reuters)
British lawmakers approved a measure to permit sanctions against people who perpetrate human-rights abuses. (Reuters)
The owners of a company that makes baby pacifiers were told it was all a mistake after they were flagged by their bank for suspicious transactions. (Bloomberg)
Artifacts taken from Iraq and smuggled into the U.S. by arts and crafts retail chain Hobby Lobby were to be returned to the country as part of an agreement between the company and the U.S. Department of Justice. (NPR)
General Anticorruption:
U.S. President Donald Trump claimed “ absolute immunity ” when asking a federal court to dismiss a lawsuit accusing him of failing to separate his business dealings from the office. (Reuters)
The trial in a civil suit aimed at recovering $46 million from Russian billionaire Roman Abramovich, oil tycoon Russian oil tycoon Eugene Shvidler, and the Russian energy company Gazprom Neft started Wednesday in Switzerland. A European bank is suing for recovery of a debt. (AP, SI)
Albert Kelly, a senior adviser to U.S. Environmental Protection Agency head Scott Pruitt, resigned this week rather than explain to lawmakers why he was banned from the banking industry. (TIF)
Attorneys for Sara Netanyahu, wife of Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, said she would reimburse the state if she is not indicted on charges of misusing government funds. (Haaretz)
Court documents made public this week show Germany-based healthcare company Fresenius Medical Care & Co. said it found “blatant fraud” at U.S. drugmaker Akorn after it agreed to buy the company. Akorn is suing to hold Fresenius to the deal. (Reuters, MD)
Regulators in New Zealand want assurances from lenders owned by Australian banks that they aren’t engaged in the sort of wrongdoing their parent companies are accused of committing.
